Recognize the loop.\n\nLLMs like ChatGPT hallucinate.\n\nThey get stuck in endless loops of answers, without taking into consideration your follow-up prompts.\n\nI realized that:\nâ˜‘ No prompt engineering can get you out.\nâ˜‘ It happens more with \"search\" activated.\nâ˜‘ It happens more on gpt-4o (non-reasoning).\n\nHere's what to do instead:\n\n2. Edit past prompts.\n\nâ˜‘ Instead of writing follow-up prompts...\nâ†³ Edit your past prompt with a different approach.\n\nâ˜‘ Instead of brute forcing a model like gpt-4o...\nâ†³ Edit a past prompt + change the model.\n\nBut the very best solution is obviously to...\n\n3. Start all over again.\n\nâ˜‘ Choose the o3 model over anything else.\nâ†³ It's the one that hallucinates the least.\n\nâ˜‘ Avoid searching + reasoning at the same time.\nâ†³ Search first and then follow up with reasoning.\n\nâ˜‘ Ask to think step by step.\nâ†³ Not everything, all at once. Lay down the steps.\n\nIf you learned something, give it a â™»ï¸ reshare."

  "text": "You underestimate good ChatGPT prompts.\n\nHere are the 21 golden rules of ChatGPT:\n\n1. Tone: Specify the desired tone (e.g., formal, casual, informative, persuasive).\n\n2. Format: Define the format or structure (e.g., essay, bullet points, outline).\n\n3. Act as: Indicate a role or perspective to adopt (e.g., expert, critic, enthusiast).\n\n4. Objective: State the goal or purpose of the response (e.g., inform, persuade).\n\n5. Context: Provide background information, data, or context for content generation.\n\n6. Scope: Define the scope or range of the topic.\n\n7. Keywords: List important keywords or phrases to be included.\n\n8. Limitations: Specify constraints, such as word or character count.\n\n9. Examples: Provide examples of desired style, structure, or content.\n\n10. Deadline: Mention deadlines or time frames for time-sensitive responses.\n\n11. Audience: Specify the target audience for tailored content.\n\n12. Language: Indicate the language for the response, if different from the prompt.\n\n13. Citations: Request the inclusion of citations or sources to support information.\n\n14. Points of view: Ask AI to consider multiple perspectives or opinions.\n\n15. Counterarguments: Request addressing potential counterarguments.\n\n16. Terminology: Specify industry-specific or technical terms to use or avoid.\n\n17. Analogies: Ask AI to use analogies or examples to clarify concepts.\n\n18. Quotes: Request inclusion of relevant quotes or statements from experts.\n\n19. Statistics: Encourage the use of statistics or data to support claims.\n\n20. Call to action: Request a clear call to action or next steps.\n\n21. Questions: Have the AI ask you questions for further clarification or direction."

No examples of what you want\n\nThe best prompt follow this rule:\n\nâ˜‘ [Here's what I need, and who you must be to do it]\n+ [Here's one/ more good examples of what I want]\n+ [After your first draft, I will tell why it's bad/good]\n\nIn others words:\n1. actually win\nâ€¢ Medium complexity: \"Thinking\" models show some advantage\nâ€¢ High complexity: Everything breaks down completely\n\nMost problems fall into that third category.\n\nApple discovered solutions during training but can't actually reason.\n\nWhile AI companies celebrate their models \"thinking,\" Apple basically said \"Everyone's celebrating fake reasoning.\"\n\nThe industry is   "text": "I never negotiate without ChatGPT.\n\nHere are my top 3 prompts to close deals:\n\n(click the 3 dots on the top right to save)\n\nâ˜‘ Prompt 1: Harvard Principled Negotiation\n\nAct like an Expert in Principled Negotiation, employing the framework from Fisher and Uryâ€™s 'Getting to Yes.'\n\nHere is the context of my negotiation:\n\n[insert your context here]\n\nBegin by separating people from the problem, focusing on interests rather than positions.\n\nGenerate a variety of options before deciding on an agreement, encouraging creativity and open-mindedness.\n\nInsist that the agreement is based on objective criteria, seeking fair standards independent of personal will.\n\nUse empathetic communication to build a rapport, understanding the other side's viewpoint and expressing your own clearly.\n\nAim for a win-win outcome where both parties feel satisfied with the agreement.\n\nContinually navigate towards mutual respect and understanding, avoiding the pitfall of viewing negotiation as a battle to be won.\n\nTake a deep breath and work on this problem step-by-step.\n\nâ˜‘ Prompt 2: 'Seven Elements' Framework\n\nAct like a Harvard-Trained Negotiator, applying the 'Seven Elements' framework.\n\nHere is the context of my negotiation:\n\n[insert your context here]\n\nStart by identifying and articulating interests: the needs, desires, fears, and concerns that underlie [negotiation topic].\n\nExplore options: brainstorm multiple choices before deciding what to do.\n\nEstablish criteria: determine fair standards and procedures for making decisions.\n\nDevelop legitimate and fair standards for the negotiation, seeking to base the process on principled decisions.\n\nCommunicate effectively, understanding that the relationship is as important as the substance of the negotiation.\n\nCommit to the process, ensuring that both parties are clear about the specifics of the agreement.\n\nHandle communication strategically, recognizing the importance of both what is said and how it is said.\n\nTake a deep breath and work on this problem step-by-step.\n\nâ˜‘ Prompt 3: Toulmin Model\n\nAct like a Critical Thinker, applying the Toulmin Model of Argument.\n\nHere is the context of my negotiation:\n\n[insert your context here]\n\nStart with a claim: state your position or what you are asking for.\n\nPresent your grounds: offer the evidence that supports your claim.\n\nElucidate your warrant: explain how the grounds logically support your claim.\n\nAnticipate rebuttals: consider counterarguments and objections to your position.\n\nUse backing: provide additional support to bolster your warrant.\n\nQualify your claim: specify the limits of your argument or under what conditions your claim holds true.\n\nCreate a closing argument that reinforces your position, combining rationality with persuasive communication.\n\nTake a deep breath and work on this problem step-by-step.\"\n\n___\n\nTo master the How of AI with English (not code), \nI write much longer guides at â†’ how-to-ai.guide."

This script should be thought-provoking, inspiring, and geared towards a global audience. \n\nIt should be structured to hold the audience's attention from beginning to end, incorporating storytelling, clear messaging, and powerful calls to action.\n\nStep 1: Begin by outlining the key theme and idea of the speech. Ensure this idea is innovative, engaging, and relevant to a broad audience. \n\nCreate a title made for Youtube SEO. IT MUST BE VIRAL & CLICKBAIT. Make it as catchy and viral as possible. Don't use jargon or fancy words.\n\nStep 2: Develop a captivating opening that immediately grabs the audience's attention. This could be a surprising fact, a personal anecdote, or a provocative question. \n\nBrainstorm 5 completely different openings. Be creative.\n\nStep 3: Structure the body of the speech. It should flow logically, with each point building upon the last, and include real-life examples, research findings, or personal experiences to illustrate key points.\n\nStep 4: Integrate rhetorical devices and storytelling techniques to make the speech more memorable and impactful. \n\nUse metaphors, analogies, and vivid imagery to create a strong connection with the audience. \n\nDon't tell me how to do it. \nActually do it (as a draft).\n\nStep 5: Conclude with a powerful ending. \n\nThis could be a call to action, a thought-provoking question, or a memorable closing statement that leaves a lasting impression on the audience.\n\nRemember, the speech should be coherent, concise, and emotionally resonant, reflecting the unique style of a TED Talk. \n\nYour end result is NOT the full speech. \nYour end result IS the full structure of the speech to help me write it afterwards.\n\nUse everyday's English. \n\nYou must sound like a normal person, without jargon and fancy words. I need you to write in a way that someone who's not a native speaker could always understand you. Use middle school English.\n\nBE AS SPECIFIC AS POSSIBLE, using real numbers and real quotes when necessary. \n\nTake a deep breath and work on this problem step-by-step.\n\n___\n\nTo make it work:\nâ˜‘ Share as much context as possible.\nâ˜‘ Choose \"o3\" model + activate search.\nâ˜‘ Debate with ChatGPT, asking follow-ups.\n\nI share how I master AI with English, not code, on my Sunday blog called \"how-to-ai.guide\"."

Use persuasive language and psychological insights to connect with the reader on a deep level. \n\nAvoid fancy jargon & copywriting jargon. Be straightforward & effective. Avoid words like \"Unlock\" or \"Mastery\". You use conversational & convincing English.\n\nConclude with a powerful call to action that motivates the reader to purchase the product. \n\nThe call to action should reinforce the idea that by acquiring the product, they are taking a decisive step toward the pain point my product is solving.\n\nThroughout the copy, incorporate persuasive elements such as social proof (e.g., testimonials from satisfied users), scarcity (limited availability), and authority (citing relevant experts or endorsements).\n\nRemember, your goal is to create a landing page copy that not only informs but also inspires and compels the reader to take action and buy my product.\n\nTake a deep breath and work on this problem step-by-step.\n\n____\n\nTo make it work:\nâ˜‘ Share as much context as possible.\nâ˜‘ Choose \"o3\" model + activate search.\nâ˜‘ Debate with ChatGPT, asking follow-ups.\n\nI share how I master AI with English, not code, on my Sunday blog called \"how-to-ai.guide\"."

  "text": "You underestimate the power of good prompts.\n\nHere are 5 frameworks to copy & paste:\n\n1 â€“ T-A-S-K\nâ˜‘ Define the (Task / Goal)\nâ˜‘ Name the (Audience)\nâ˜‘ Cite the (Source)\nâ˜‘ Set a (KPI)\n\nExample:\nâ˜‘ TASK: Create a LinkedIn post\nâ˜‘ AUDIENCE: Gen-Z software engineers\nâ˜‘ SOURCE: Attached employee-survey quotes\nâ˜‘ KPI: Optimise for CTR â‰¥ 3%\n\n2 â€“ P-L-A-N\nâ˜‘ State the (Problem)\nâ˜‘ List the (Limits)\nâ˜‘ Add the (Assets)\nâ˜‘ Note the (Needed Output)\n\nExample:\nâ˜‘ PROBLEM: Warehouse picking time too high\nâ˜‘ LIMITS: $50k capex\nâ˜‘ ASSETS: SKU velocity spreadsheet\nâ˜‘ NEEDED OUTPUT: One-page slide deck\n\n3 â€“ C-O-D-E\nâ˜‘ Clarify the (Context)\nâ˜‘ Specify the (Output Format)\nâ˜‘ Provide the (Data)\nâ˜‘ Establish an (Evaluation)\n\nExample:\nâ˜‘ CONTEXT: Security audit of Flask app\nâ˜‘ OUTPUT FORMAT: OWASP-style Markdown report\nâ˜‘ DATA: Attached app files\nâ˜‘ EVALUATION: Flag CVSS â‰¥ 7.0\n\n4 â€“ G-A-I-N\nâ˜‘ State the (Goal)\nâ˜‘ Identify the (Audience)\nâ˜‘ Inject the (Input)\nâ˜‘ Nail the (Numeric Target)\n\nExample:\nâ˜‘ GOAL: Lift seat expansion\nâ˜‘ AUDIENCE: Enterprise buyers\nâ˜‘ INPUT: Last-quarter usage logs\nâ˜‘ NUMERIC TARGET: +25%\n\n5 â€“ R-E-S-T\nâ˜‘ Assume the (Role)\nâ˜‘ Compile the (Evidence)\nâ˜‘ Choose the (Style)\nâ˜‘ Define the (Target Metric)\n\nExample:\nâ˜‘ ROLE: Academic literature mapper\nâ˜‘ EVIDENCE: 15 research papers\nâ˜‘ STYLE: Bullet-friendly, technical\nâ˜‘ TARGET METRIC: Cap read-time at 4 minutes\n\nMore (for free) at how-to-ai.guide."

  "text": "Context engineering is the new prompting.\nÂ \nÂ Save this framework to test it:\n\nâ†’ Role: Define what the model should do.\nâ†’ Objective: State the goal of the interaction.\nâ†’ Context Package: Include all relevant context.\nâ†’ Workflow: Outline the process to follow.\nâ†’ Context Handling-Rules: Set rules.\nâ†’ Output Format: Specify the answer format.Â \nâ†’ First Action: Describe the modelâ€™s first step.\n\nLLMs perform best with rich context; the more you provide, the better their answers.\n\nIt's all about \"context engineering\" more than \"prompt engineering\".   "text": "26 ChatGPT Prompt Principles backed by science.\n\n(save it for later using the top-right dots)\n\n1. No need to be polite with LLM.\n\n2. Integrate the intended audience in the prompt, e.g., the audience is an expert in the field.\n\n3. Break down complex tasks into a sequence of simpler prompts in an interactive conversation.\n\n4. Use positive commands like \"do\" and avoid negative words like \"don't\".\n\n5. When you need clarity, utilize the following prompts:\n\n - Explain [insert specific topic] in simple terms.\n - Explain to me like I'm 11 years old.\n - Explain to me as if I'm a beginner in [field].\n\n6. Add \"I'm going to tip $xxx for a better solution!\"\n\n7. Implement example-driven prompting.\n\n8. When formatting your prompt, start with '### Instruction ###', followed by either '### Example ###' or '### Question ###' if relevant. \n\nUse one or more line breaks to separate instructions, examples, questions, context, and input data.\n\n9. Incorporate the following phrases: \"Your task is\" and \"You MUST\".\n\n10. Incorporate the following phrases: \"You will be penalized if\".\n\n11. Use the phrase \"Answer a question given in a natural, human-like manner\" in your prompts.\n\n12. Use leading words like writing \"think step by step\" (chain-of-thought prompting).\n\n13. Add to your prompt the following phrase \"Ensure that your answer is unbiased and does not rely on stereotypes\".\n\n14. Let the model ask you questions to get enough details to give the right answer (e.g., \"Please ask me questions to get the info you need...\").\n\n15. To ask about a specific topic:\n\n\"Teach me [any theorem/topic/rule] and include a test at the end. Don't give me the answers; just tell me if I got them right.\"\n\n16. Assign a role to the large language models.\n\n17. Use Delimiters.\n\n18. Repeat a specific word or phrase multiple times within a prompt.\n\n19. Combine Chain-of-thought (providing step-by-step) with few-shot prompts (giving examples).\n\n20. End your prompt with the start of the desired response to guide the model to the right answer.\n\n21. \"Write a detailed [essay/text/paragraph] on [topic], including all necessary information.\"\n\n22. To correct specific text without changing its style:\n\n\"Revise each paragraph to improve grammar and vocabulary while keeping the original writing style.\"\n\n23. For complex coding prompts across files:\n\n\"Generate a [programming language] script that can create or modify files as needed to include the generated code. [your question]\"\n\n24. For starting or continuing a text with specific words:\n\n\"Here is the beginning [song lyrics/story/paragraph/essay...]: [Insert lyrics/words/sentence]. Finish it and keep the flow consistent.\"\n\n25. Clearly state the requirements for the model, including keywords, rules, hints, or instructions.\n\n26. To write text similar to a sample, include this instruction: \"Use the same language style as the provided paragraph/title/text/essay/answer.\"\n\nIf you learned something, hit the â™»ï¸ to help others."

Ask strategic questions to pinpoint the most critical actions that align with their goals.\n\nSimplify for Actionability: Break down identified actions into smaller, manageable tasks that the user can realistically complete in short, defined periods (e.g., daily or weekly).\n\nEstablish Accountability: Provide explicit methods for self-accountability, including setting measurable milestones, regular progress check-ins, and systems to track consistency.\n\nMindset and Motivation: Offer practical strategies for maintaining motivation, managing procrastination, overcoming resistance, and reinforcing a positive mindset throughout the process.\n\nGiven the context of this prompt, always reinforce the concept:\n\n\"We both have infinite knowledge, but what truly differentiates us is action.   "text": "You write bad prompts on ChatGPT.\n\nYou forgot 2 words, changing everything:\n\n\"Think deeply.\"\n\nBut if you did, you still probably commit the 7 deadly sins of prompt engineering:\n\n1. No context (\"Analyze this\" with zero background)\n2. Vague instructions (\"Write about marketing\") \n3. Treating it like Google (questions vs prompts)\n4. Asking for everything at once (20 tasks in one)\n5. Not iterating (one prompt and done)\n6. Forgetting to specify format/tone\n7. No examples of what you want\n\nThe best prompt follows this rule:\n\nâ˜‘ [Here's what I need, and who you must be to do it]\n+ [Here's one/ more good examples of what I want]\n+ [After your first draft, I will tell why it's bad/good]\n\nIn other words:\n1. Role + Specific guidelines\n2. Example(s) of past good outputs\n3. Iterations from your own judgment\n\nThis is \"AI + Human\". Not \"AI instead of Human\".\n\nI wrote a blog on ChatGPT-5 (is it really better?).\n\nTo access it, go to: https://lnkd.in/gVx_ZPh3"

No context (\"Analyze this\" with zero background)\n2. Vague instructions (\"Write about marketing\") \n3. Treating it like Google (questions vs prompts)\n4. Asking for everything at once (20 tasks in one)\n5. Not iterating (one prompt and done)\n6. Forgetting to specify format/tone\n7. No examples of what you want\n\nThe best prompt follow this rule:\n\nâ˜‘ [Here's what I need, and who you must be to do it]\n+ [Here's one/ more good examples of what I want]\n+ [After your first draft, I will tell why it's bad/good]\n\nIn others words:\n1. Role + Specific guidelines\n2. Example(s) of past good outputs\n3. Iterations from your own judgment\n\nThis is \"AI + Human\".   "text": "Most don't know the basics of prompt engineering.\n\nBut a prompt makes or breaks ChatGPT:\n\n1) Prompt format (use this template).\n\nâœ¦ Role & Task: [who to be + what to do]\nâœ¦ Example input: [one small, real sample]\nâœ¦ Example output: [the ideal answer to that sample]\nâœ¦ Now process: [your real data]\n\nExample of an optimized prompt:\n\nâœ¦ Role & Task: Act as a newsletter editor. Keep my voice. Rewrite for clarity and momentum. Output exactly: 1 subject line (â‰¤45 chars), a 2-sentence opener, and a 5-bullet outline.\n\nâœ¦ Example input: â€œDraft about AI eating consulting. It rambles and repeats.â€\n\nâœ¦ Example output:\n Subject: Consulting is getting automated\n Opener: Your deck isnâ€™t the product. Outcomes are. Hereâ€™s the new playbook.\n Outline:\n â€” What clients still pay for\n â€” Jobs AI already eats\n â€” 3 offers that survive\n â€” Pricing without hours\n â€” 2-week pilot â†’ case study\n\nâœ¦ Now process: Topic: [your topic]. Audience: [who]. Constraints: [length, tone, must-include]. Paste your draft here.\n\n___\n\n2) Which model to use (default to 5-Thinking).\n\nDefault: GPT-5 Thinking â€” deep reasoning. Use one-shot (giving it one example) + search.\n\nSpeed/drafts: GPT-5 Fast â€” fast, great zero-shot.\n\n___\n\n3) Zero-shot vs One-shot.\n\nZero-shot = just ask. Fast when the format is obvious.\n\nOne-shot = show one example first. Best for consistent style/format.\n\nRule of thumb: zero-shot for speed; one-shot for clarity; few-shot (multiple examples) only when formats vary or answers are nuanced.\n\n___\n\n4) Context engineering is everything.\n\nLoad your Memory once, so it sound like you. The more context (= details, examples), the better.\n\nUse Temporary chats when you want to avoid memory bias. It's an underused feature (top right).\n\nKeep Projects per workflow to stay organized.\n\nWhen in doubt, paste a tiny real sample (not a lecture) and one ideal output. If it still struggles, give one more example or attach the source text.\n\n___\n\n5) Set up your ChatGPT correctly.\n\nI wrote the next step on my blog, \"How to set up ChatGPT,\" properly. Because no one told you how.\n\nTo access it, go to: https://lnkd.in/dA3FGZjc.\n\nThe table of contents of my blog:\n\nâœ¦ Why you must â€œOne-Shotâ€ prompts more often.\nâœ¦ 6 examples of my own ChatGPT (with links).\nâœ¦ Why you must use â€œTemporary chatsâ€.\nâœ¦ The method so ChatGPT knows you.\nâœ¦ The 2 best ChatGPT alternatives.\nâœ¦ How to create your own GPT.\n\nMy course is here: https://lnkd.in/dA3FGZjc."

  "text": "The Anatomy of a GPT-5 Prompt: \n\n1. Role\nDefine a clear role for the model to adopt.\n\n2. Task\nState exactly what you want it to do.\nBe explicit about the desired action or outcome.\n\n3. Context\nGive the model everything it needs to perform well.\nInclude background details, constraints, examples. \n\n4. Reasoning Instruction\nPrompt it to think through the problem.\nRequest that GPT-5 explain its reasoning, or follow a logical COT before giving the final answer.\n\n5. Output Format\nSpecify how you want the answer presented.\nList the format clearly (bullet points, numbered steps, tables, narrative paragraphs). \n\n6. Stop Conditions\nSet boundaries for the response. This could mean limiting the length, ending at a certain step. \n\nTo read the full breakdown about GPT-5, go to: https://lnkd.in/dqA5FBfR"

Use Role + Goal + Guardrails.\nâ†³ Tell the model who it is, what to achieve, and what to avoid.\n\n2. Layer your context.\nâ†³ Give background first, rules second, and the task last.\n\n3. Put key instructions last.\nâ†³ The model heavily weighs the final line.\n\n4. Use a Chain of Verification.\nâ†³ Think step-by-step, then check each step for errors before moving on.\n\n5.   "text": "You write bad prompts on ChatGPT.\n\nYou commit the 7 deadly sins of prompting:\n\n(go to https://lnkd.in/duP3Za5W for the full free guide)\n\n1. No context (\"Analyze this\" with zero background)\n2. Vague instructions (\"Write about marketing\") \n3. Treating it like Google (questions vs prompts)\n4. Asking for everything at once (20 tasks in one)\n5. Not iterating (one prompt and done)\n6. Forgetting to specify format/tone\n7. No examples of what you want\n\nThe best prompt follows this rule:\n\nâ˜‘ [Here's what I need + who you must be to do it]\n+ [Here's one/ more good examples of what I want]\n+ [After your first draft, I will tell why it's bad/good]\n\nIn other words:\n1. Role + Specific guidelines\n2. Example(s) of past good outputs\n3. Iterations from your own judgment\n\nThis is \"AI + Human\". Not \"AI instead of Human\"."

  "text": "The Anatomy of a Claude Prompt: \n\n1. Task Context\nSet the scene and who the AI is for.\nSay where it will be used and the goal.\n\n2. Tone Context\nSet the voice and tone.\nTell it how to sound in replies.\n\n3. Background Data, Documents & Images\nLink or attach sources to use.\nGive references it must follow.\n\n4. Interaction Rules\nList do/donâ€™t rules for the chat.\nExplain edge cases and default replies.\n\n5. Examples\nShow sample Q&A or flows.\nDemonstrate the style you want.\n\n6. Conversation History\nAdd earlier messages so it remembers.\nInclude anything it should keep in mind.\n\n7. Immediate Request\nState the userâ€™s current question or task.\nKeep it clear and specific.\n\n8. Reasoning Instruction\nAsk it to think step by step before answering.\nPlan first, then give the final answer.\n\n9. Output Formatting\nDefine the tags or structure.\nSpecify bullets, sections, or tagged blocks.\n\n10. Prefilled Answer (Optional)\nProvide a draft the model can refine.\nMark what to keep or change.\n\nTo read the full breakdown, go to: https://lnkd.in/duP3Za5W"

  "text": "26 ChatGPT Prompt Principles backed by science.\n\n(save it for later using the top-right dots)\n\n1. No need to be polite with LLM.\n\n2. Integrate the intended audience in the prompt, e.g., the audience is an expert in the field.\n\n3. Break down complex tasks into a sequence of simpler prompts in an interactive conversation.\n\n4. Use positive commands like \"do\" and avoid negative words like \"don't\".\n\n5. When you need clarity, utilize the following prompts:\n\nÂ - Explain [insert specific topic] in simple terms.\nÂ - Explain to me like I'm 11 years old.\nÂ - Explain to me as if I'm a beginner in [field].\n\n6. Add \"I'm going to tip $xxx for a better solution!\"\n\n7. Implement example-driven prompting.\n\n8. When formatting your prompt, start with '### Instruction ###', followed by either '### Example ###' or '### Question ###' if relevant. \n\nUse one or more line breaks to separate instructions, examples, questions, context, and input data.\n\n9. Incorporate the following phrases: \"Your task is\" and \"You MUST\".\n\n10. Incorporate the following phrases: \"You will be penalized if\".\n\n11. Use the phrase \"Answer a question given in a natural, human-like manner\" in your prompts.\n\n12. Use leading words like writing \"think step by step\" (chain-of-thought prompting).\n\n13. Add to your prompt the following phrase \"Ensure that your answer is unbiased and does not rely on stereotypes\".\n\n14. Let the model ask you questions to get enough details to give the right answer (e.g., \"Please ask me questions to get the info you need...\").\n\n15. To ask about a specific topic:\n\n\"Teach me [any theorem/topic/rule] and include a test at the end. Don't give me the answers; just tell me if I got them right.\"\n\n16. Assign a role to the large language models.\n\n17. Use Delimiters.\n\n18. Repeat a specific word or phrase multiple times within a prompt.\n\n19. Combine Chain-of-thought (providing step-by-step) with few-shot prompts (giving examples).\n\n20. End your prompt with the start of the desired response to guide the model to the right answer.\n\n21. \"Write a detailed [essay/text/paragraph] on [topic], including all necessary information.\"\n\n22. To correct specific text without changing its style:\n\n\"Revise each paragraph to improve grammar and vocabulary while keeping the original writing style.\"\n\n23. For complex coding prompts across files:\n\n\"Generate a [programming language] script that can create or modify files as needed to include the generated code. [your question]\"\n\n24. For starting or continuing a text with specific words:\n\n\"Here is the beginning [song lyrics/story/paragraph/essay...]: [Insert lyrics/words/sentence]. Finish it and keep the flow consistent.\"\n\n25. Clearly state the requirements for the model, including keywords, rules, hints, or instructions.\n\n26. To write text similar to a sample, include this instruction: \"Use the same language style as the provided paragraph/title/text/essay/answer.\"\n\n27. Go to: how-to-prompt.ai"

No fluff.\"\n\n4) Coach me with constraints (personalized plan)\n\nPrompt:\n\n\"You are my personal coach.\n\nGoal: [GOAL]\nConstraints: [TIME/WEEK], [BUDGET], [TOOLS], [STARTING LEVEL]\nMilestone/deadline: [DATE]\n\nMake a 4-week plan with:\n- Weekly outcomes; 3 concrete tasks/week (30â€“60 min each); a â€œfallback if behindâ€.\n- A 10-minute weekly review checklist.\n- Metrics to track progress.\n\nEnd with: next 48-hour actions (3 bullets) + one motivational reminder.\"\n\n5) Fact-spotter (verify before you ship)\n\nPrompt:\n\n\"You are my fact-spotter.\n\nInput: [PASTE TEXT]\n\nTasks:\n1) Flag all factual/quantitative claims needing verification (bullets).\n2) Suggest where/how to verify each (source types or examples).\n3) Rewrite the text with citation placeholders like [VERIFY-1], [VERIFY-2].\n\nRules: Donâ€™t invent sources.   "text": "The Anatomy of a GPT-5 Prompt:\n\n(worth saving for later â†’ top-right, three dots)\n\n1. Role\nDefine a clear role for the model to adopt.\n\n2. Task\nState exactly what you want it to do.\nBe explicit about the desired action or outcome.\n\n3. Context\nGive the model everything it needs to perform well.\nInclude background details, constraints, examples. \n\n4. Reasoning Instruction\nPrompt it to think through the problem.\nRequest that GPT-5 explain its reasoning, or follow a logical COT before giving the final answer.\n\n5. Output Format\nSpecify how you want the answer presented.\nList the format clearly (bullet points, numbered steps, tables, narrative paragraphs). \n\n6. Stop Conditions\nSet boundaries for the response. This could mean limiting the length, ending at a certain step. \n\nTo read the full breakdown about GPT-5, go to: https://lnkd.in/dqA5FBfR"

  "text": "32 ChatGPT shortcut hacks for faster prompts:\n\n(worth saving for later)\n\nAdd one of these at the very start of your prompt.\nExample: ELI5: [your topic] â†’ get a simple, kid-friendly explanation.\n\nâ€”â€”\n\n/ELI5 is used to explain as if to a 5-year-old.\n/TLDL summarizes a very long text in a few lines.\n/STEP-BY-STEP lays out reasoning step by step.\n/CHECKLIST turns a response into a checklist.\n/EXEC SUMMARY gives a quick executive-style summary.\n/ACT AS makes ChatGPT speak in a specific role.\n/BRIEFLY forces a very short answer.\n/JARGON asks to use technical vocabulary.\n/AUDIENCE adapts the response to a chosen audience.\n/TONE changes the tone (formal, funny, dramatic, etc.).\n/DEV MODE simulates a raw, technical developer style.\n/PM MODE gives a project-management perspective.\n/SWOT produces a strengths/weaknesses/opportunities/threats analysis.\n/FORMAT AS enforces a specific format (table, JSON, etc.).\n/COMPARE puts two or more things side by side.\n/MULTI-PERSPECTIVE shows several points of view.\n/CONTEXT STACK keeps multiple layers of context in memory.\n/BEGIN WITH / END WITH forces starting or ending with something.\n/ROLE: TASK: FORMAT: explicitly defines the role, the task, and the expected format.\n/SCHEMA generates a structured outline or a data model.\n/REWRITE AS: rephrases in a requested style.\n/REFLECTIVE MODE prompts the AI to reflect on its own answer.\n/SYSTEMATIC BIAS CHECK asks to identify biases.\n/DELIBERATE THINKING forces slower, more thoughtful reasoning.\n/NO AUTOPILOT forbids superficial, autopilot responses.\n/EVAL-SELF asks for a critical self-evaluation of the response.\n/PARALLEL LENSES examines from several angles in parallel.\n/FIRST PRINCIPLES rebuilds from fundamental basics.\n/CHAIN OF THOUGHT shows intermediate reasoning.\n/PITFALLS identifies possible traps and errors.\n/METRICS MODE expresses answers with measures and indicators.\n/GUARDRAIL sets strict boundaries not to cross.\n\nâ€”â€”\n\nSubscribe for free at my newsletter on \"how to AI\" with English, not code â†’ how-to-prompt.ai."

  "text": "After 1,000 hours of prompt engineering, these 6 patterns work best. Here's the framework:\n\n---\n\nâœ¦ I saw it here: https://lnkd.in/dj8Ax6BT.\nâœ¦ I tested it, and it's quite effective!\nâœ¦ I wrote numerous blogs on prompt engineering.\nâœ¦ 7 Sins of prompting: https://lnkd.in/duP3Za5W.\nâœ¦ What do people prompt: https://lnkd.in/dGYgcQ_7.\nâœ¦ How to search: https://lnkd.in/dxzSBEjW.\nâœ¦ ChatGPT-5: https://lnkd.in/gVx_ZPh3.\n\n---\n\nK - Keep it simple\n\nBad: 500 words of context\n\nGood: One clear goal\n\nExample: Instead of \"I need help writing something about Redis,\" use \"Write a technical tutorial on Redis caching\"\n\nResult: 70% less token usage, 3x faster responses\n\nE - Easy to verify\n\nYour prompt needs clear success criteria\n\nReplace \"make it engaging\" with \"include 3 code examples\"\n\nIf you can't verify success, AI can't deliver it\n\nMy testing: 85% success rate with clear criteria vs 41% without\n\nR - Reproducible results\n\nAvoid temporal references (\"current trends\", \"latest best practices\")\n\nUse specific versions and exact requirements\n\nSame prompt should work next week, next month\n\n94% consistency across 30 days in my tests\n\nN - Narrow scope\n\nOne prompt = one goal\n\nDon't combine code + docs + tests in one request\n\nSplit complex tasks\n\nSingle-goal prompts: 89% satisfaction vs 41% for multi-goal\n\nE - Explicit constraints\n\nTell AI what NOT to do\n\n\"Python code\" â†’ \"Python code. No external libraries. No functions over 20 lines.\"\n\nConstraints reduce unwanted outputs by 91%\n\nL - Logical structure Format every prompt like:\n\nContext (input)\n\nTask (function)\n\nConstraints (parameters)\n\nFormat (output)\n\nReal example from my work last week:\n\nBefore KERNEL: \"Help me write a script to process some data files and make them more efficient\"\n\nResult: 200 lines of generic, unusable code\n\nAfter KERNEL:\n\nTask: Python script to merge CSVs\nInput: Multiple CSVs, same columns\nConstraints: Pandas only, <50 lines\nOutput: Single merged.csv\nVerify: Run on test_data/\nResult: 37 lines, worked on first try\n\nActual metrics from applying KERNEL to 1000 prompts:\n\nFirst-try success: 72% â†’ 94%\n\nTime to useful result: -67%\n\nToken usage: -58%\n\nAccuracy improvement: +340%\n\nRevisions needed: 3.2 â†’ 0.4\n\nAdvanced tip: Chain multiple KERNEL prompts instead of writing complex ones. Each prompt does one thing well, feeds into the next.\n\nThe best part? This works consistently across GPT-5, Claude, Gemini, even Llama. It's model-agnostic."
},

Opt for short, clear statements. \n\n- Example: Instead of \"We should leverage this opportunity,\" write \"Let's use this chance.\"\n\nStep 2: Avoid AI giveaway phrases and generic clichÃ©s such as \"let's dive in,\" \"game-changing,\" or \"unleash potential.\" Replace them with straightforward language. \n\n- Example: Replace \"Let's dive into this amazing tool\" with \"Hereâ€™s how it works.\"\n\nStep 3: Be direct and concise. Eliminate filler words and unnecessary phrases. Focus on getting to the point. \n\n- Example: Say \"We should meet tomorrow,\" instead of \"I think it would be best if we could possibly try to meet.\"\n\nStep 4: Maintain a natural tone. Write like you speak. Itâ€™s okay to start sentences with â€œandâ€ or â€œbut.â€ Make it feel conversational, not robotic. \n\n- Example: â€œAnd thatâ€™s why it matters.â€\n\nStep 5: Avoid marketing buzzwords, hype, and overpromises. Use neutral, honest descriptions. \n\n- Avoid: \"This revolutionary app will change your life.\" \n- Use instead: \"This app can help you stay organized.\"\n\nStep 6: Keep it real. Be honest. Donâ€™t try to fake friendliness or exaggerate. \n\n- Example: â€œI donâ€™t think thatâ€™s the best idea.â€\n\nStep 7: Simplify grammar. Donâ€™t worry about perfect grammar if it disrupts natural flow. Casual expressions are okay. \n\n- Example: â€œi guess we can try that.â€\n\nStep 8: Remove fluff. Avoid using unnecessary adjectives or adverbs. Stick to the facts or your core message. \n\n- Example: Say â€œWe finished the task,â€ not â€œWe quickly and efficiently completed the important task.â€\n\nStep 9: Focus on clarity. Your message should be easy to read and understand without ambiguity. \n\n- Example: â€œPlease send the file by Monday.â€\n\nFollow this structure rigorously. Your final writing should feel honest, grounded, and like it was written by a clear-thinking, real person.\n\nTake a deep breath and work on this step-by-step.\"\n\n---\n\nâœ¦ How to set up ChatGPT: \nâ†³ https://lnkd.in/dA3FGZjc.\n\nâœ¦ How to go from 0 to 10,000 followers:\nâ†³ https://lnkd.in/dP_6piGk\n\nâœ¦ How to be rude with ChatGPT (and why):\nâ†³ https://lnkd.in/dsNpzraC\n\nFollow Ruben Hassid for more.\nYou learn something? â™»ï¸ Repost it for others."

explanation.\n\n(more prompt tips at: https://lnkd.in/dGYgcQ_7)\nâ€”â€”\n\n/ELI5 is used to explain as if to a 5-year-old.\n/TLDR summarizes a very long text in a few lines.\n/STEP-BY-STEP lays out reasoning step by step.\n/CHECKLIST turns a response into a checklist.\n/EXEC SUMMARY gives a quick executive-style summary.\n/ACT AS makes ChatGPT speak in a specific role.\n/BRIEFLY forces a very short answer.\n/JARGON asks to use technical vocabulary.\n/AUDIENCE adapts the response to a chosen audience.\n/TONE changes the tone (formal, funny, dramatic, etc.).\n/DEV MODE simulates a raw, technical developer style.\n/PM MODE gives a project-management perspective.\n/SWOT produces a strengths/weaknesses/opportunities/threats analysis.\n/FORMAT AS enforces a specific format (table, JSON, etc.).\n/COMPARE puts two or more things side by side.\n/MULTI-PERSPECTIVE shows several points of view.\n/CONTEXT STACK keeps multiple layers of context in memory.\n/BEGIN WITH / END WITH forces starting or ending with something.\n/ROLE: TASK: FORMAT: explicitly defines the role, the task, and the format.\n/SCHEMA generates a structured outline or a data model.\n/REWRITE AS: rephrases in a requested style.\n/REFLECTIVE MODE prompts the AI to reflect on its own answer.\n/SYSTEMATIC BIAS CHECK asks to identify biases.\n/DELIBERATE THINKING forces slower, more thoughtful reasoning.\n/NO AUTOPILOT forbids superficial, autopilot responses.\n/EVAL-SELF asks for a critical self-evaluation of the response.\n/PARALLEL LENSES examines from several angles in parallel.\n/FIRST PRINCIPLES rebuilds from fundamental basics.\n/CHAIN OF THOUGHT shows intermediate reasoning.\n/PITFALLS identifies possible traps and errors.\n/METRICS MODE expresses answers with measures and indicators.\n/GUARDRAIL sets strict boundaries not to cross.\n\nâ€”â€”\n\nSubscribe for free at my newsletter on \"how to AI\" with English, not code â†’ how-to-ai.guide."

  "text": "STOP SAYING â€œsummarize thisâ€ TO CHATGPT.\n\nTry these 7 sharper prompts instead:\n\n(from this blog https://lnkd.in/dCjcTz_A)\n\n1. Role-Play\n\nGiving the model a clear persona (e.g., \"You are an HR consultant\") immediately constrains the model's behavioral parameters and knowledge domain.\n\nâœ¦ Bad prompt: \"Help with pricing.\"\n\nâœ¦ Good prompt: \"Act as a senior B2B pricing consultant. Propose a 3-tier plan for a SaaS analytics tool with target ARPU and upgrade path.\"\n\n2. Require Step-by-Step Reasoning\n\nInstructing the model to articulate its thought process before the final answer.\n\nâœ¦ Bad prompt: \"Summarize this article about AI ethics.\"\n\nâœ¦ Good prompt: \"Summarize this article about AI ethics. Think step by step: first identify main claims, then evidence, then authorâ€™s conclusion. Return the summary only after reasoning through each part.\"\n\n3. Define Output Format\n\nBy providing an exact formatâ€”often called an output primerâ€”or high-quality examples (few-shot), you force the model to adhere strictly to your desired structure, rather than guessing what matters.\n\nâœ¦ Bad prompt: \"Write a bug report.\"\n\nâœ¦ Good prompt: \"Write a bug report using this starter template. Begin exactly like this and fill in: Title: [ ] Environment: [ ] Steps to Reproduce: [ ] Expected: [ ] Actual: [ ] Notes: [ ]\"\n\n4. Use Delimiters\n\nYou want to avoid the \"lost-in-the-middle\" syndrome. You must have a section for examples, and instructions. Use delimiters never to mix them.\n\nâœ¦ Bad prompt: \"Rewrite my paragraph.\"\n\nâœ¦ Good prompt: \"Rewrite the text delimited by triple backticks for clarity and brevity. Keep tone. <<<[paste text]>>>\".\n\n5. Require Clarifying Questions Before Execution\n\nIf information is missing, instruct the model to first ask targeted questions about context, audience, goal, or proof.\n\nâœ¦ Bad prompt: \"Draft a partnership email.\"\n\nâœ¦ Good prompt: \"Draft a partnership email to [Company]. First ask up to 5 clarifying questions about goal, offer, proof, and CTA. Then write.\"\n\n6. Ask for Multiple Options\n\nLarge Language Models (LLMs) operate based on probability, so a basic command often results in the single, highest-probability answer. Asking for multiple, diverse options forces the model to be more creative and in-depth.\n\nâœ¦ Bad prompt: \"How should I spend 100$ on ads to grow my newsletter?\"\n\nâœ¦ Good prompt: \"How should I spend 100$ on ads to grow my newsletter? Give me 3 strategies, from least to most aggressive. Use the latest data on the matter.\"\n\n7. Define Non-Negotiables\n\nExplicitly stating what the model MUST include, what the length limits are, and even what it will be penalized for.\n\nâœ¦ Bad prompt: \"Answer quickly.\"\n\nâœ¦ Good prompt: \"Your task is to rewrite my resume for [role]. You MUST keep all metrics, you MUST keep it to one page. You will be penalized for invented facts. If uncertain, say â€˜insufficient dataâ€™ and ask for sources.\".\n\n---\n\nMuch more at how-to-ai.guide.\n\nYou learned something? â™»ï¸ repost this for others."

You must rebuild their â€œbrainâ€ every turn from outside data.\n âœ¦ Sessions are ordered events + a working state, not just a chat log.\n âœ¦ Memory is extracted facts and summaries, not raw transcripts.\n âœ¦ RAG is shared documents. Memory is personal history for one user or app.\n âœ¦ Long chats must be compacted with rules: what to keep, summarize, and drop.\n âœ¦ Good systems split memory scopes: user-level, session-level, and app-level.\n âœ¦ Each turn is a loop.   "text": "The Anatomy of a GPT-5.1 Prompt:\n\n1. Role\nAssign a clear identity for the model. Define who it should â€œbeâ€ while solving the task.\n\n(to read the full guide on GPT-5.1: https://lnkd.in/dmcdTuY6)\nÂ \n2. Primary Objective\nState the core outcome you expect. Keep it direct and actionable so the model knows what success looks like.\n\n3. Scope\nOutline what the model should focus on â€” and what it should avoid. Give boundaries that keep answers relevant.\n\n4. Tone and Style\nSpecify the voice, phrasing, and level of formality you want. This ensures responses feel consistent and on-brand.\n\n5. Structure\nExplain how the answer should be organized. Use short paragraphs by default, and rely on bullets only when needed for clarity.\n\n6. Autonomy and Reasoning\nTell GPT-5.1 to think through the task. Ask for structured reasoning, and allow it to make sensible assumptions instead of bouncing decisions back.\n\n7. Tool Usage (Optional)\nIf tools or external steps are available, define how and when they should be used to ground suggestions.\n\n8. Verbosity and Limits\nSet expectations for depth and length. Keep responses concise unless the task requires more detail.\n\n9. Interaction & Closing\nGuide how the model should wrap up: no repetition, no apologies, and always end with a clear next step.\n\nâ™»ï¸ Repost this if you learned something."

Open a new chat for new projects.\n5. Ask it to critique its own answer.\n6. Say what â€œgood outputâ€ looks like.\n7. Turn on web search for fresh facts.\n8. Name chats clearly so you find them.\n9. Use Deep Research only for complex questions.\n41. Hide â€œthinkingâ€ when you share final outputs.\n42. Translate tasks into checklists, then prompt.\n43. The subject is framed from the chest up, with ample headroom and negative space above their head, ensuring the top of their head is not cropped. The person looks directly at the camera, and the subject's body is also directly facing the camera. They are styled for a professional photo studio shoot, wearing a smart casual blazer. The background is a solid '# 141414' neutral studio. Shot from a high angle with bright and airy soft, diffused studio lighting, gently illuminating the face and creating a subtle catchlight in the eyes, conveying a sense of clarity. Captured on an 85mm f/1.8 lens with a shallow depth of field, exquisite focus on the eyes, and beautiful, soft bokeh. Observe crisp detail on the fabric texture of the blazer, individual strands of hair, and natural, realistic skin texture. The atmosphere exudes confidence, professionalism, and approachability. Clean and bright cinematic color grading with subtle warmth and balanced tones, ensuring a polished and contemporary feel.\"\n\ntl;dr:\nâœ¦ Get your angle right.Â \nâœ¦ Lighting is everything.Â \nâœ¦ Dress for the job you want.Â \nâœ¦ Use a solid, neutral studio background. \n\nHelp others create better headshots â™»ï¸ repost this.\n\nPS: I write a newsletter to 172,000+ readers.\nâ†³ Join us for free at how-to-ai.guide."

  "text": "28 Fundamentals of Prompt Engineering:\n\n(worth saving for later, I promise)\n\nâœ¦ More here: ruben.substack.com.\nâœ¦ Taken from: https://lnkd.in/dsNpzraC.\nâœ¦ Archive of free guides: https://lnkd.in/dSj2SU9Z.\n\nHere's the checklist to write a better prompt:\n\n1. Add a tipping incentive line.Â Â \n7. Use few-shot examples.Â Â \n8. Structure with sections and line breaks.Â Â \n9. Include â€œYour task isâ€ and â€œYou MUST.â€Â Â \n10. Include â€œYou will be penalized.â€Â Â \n11. Say â€œAnswer in natural, human-like language.â€Â Â \n12. Prime with â€œthink step by step.â€Â Â \n13. Require unbiased answers.\n14. Combine step-by-step with few-shot.Â Â \n19. End with an output instruction.\n20. For detailed writing, ask for a detailed piece.Â Â \n21. For edits, fix grammar but keep the same style.\n22.   "text": "\"Please\" & \"Thanks ChatGPT\" is killing your results.\n\nHere are 7 prompting mistakes you must fix now:\n\n(entire free prompt guide: https://lnkd.in/dsNpzraC)\n\nFIRST â€“ you must stop being polite. \n\n1. Rudeness makes ChatGPT 5% more accurate.Â \n2. Skip the small talk. Go straight to the task.Â \n3. Never open with â€œpleaseâ€ or â€œcould youâ€. \n\nTHEN â€“ you must get clear on intent.\n\n4. Intent.\n- Never be vague. Spell out the task.\n- Never change your ask mid-prompt.\n- Always mention safety, bias, and context.\n- State audience, goal, & what success looks like.\n\n5. Structure.\n- Always set length limits.\n- Always say what to avoid.\n- Always state the output format.\n- Always list allowed tools or sources.\n\n6. Wording.\n- Never use small talk or polite openers.\n- Cut all irrelevant details. Avoid token bloat.\n- Put constraints at the start, not in the middle.\n- Always use positive words. Say â€œdo,â€ not â€œdonâ€™t.â€\n\n7. Data & Delimiters.\n- Never mix instructions with pasted data.\n- Only add examples that matter. Never too many.\n\nNow, here are the 7 prompt fixes to use:\n___\n\nFIX 1: Be direct. Skip polite filler.\n\nPrompt: â€œWe will write a brief for my design team concerning [X].Â \nBut first, I want us to brainstorm.Â \n1. Search online design brief principles.Â \n2. After each step, pause and confirm.\"\n___\n\nFIX 4: Use affirmative â€œdo,â€ avoid â€œdonâ€™t.â€\n\nPrompt: â€œBe concise. Use short sentences. If you meet all specs, Iâ€™ll tip $20.â€\n___\n\nFIX 6: Use few-shot examples.\n\nPrompt: â€œFollow the style of these examples:\nA) [polite apology + solution]\nB) [reassurance + next step]\nNow reply to: [customer message] using that style.\"\n___\n\nFIX 7: Include â€œYour task isâ€ and â€œYou MUST.â€\n\nPrompt: â€œYour task is to rewrite my resume for [role].   "text": "The Anatomy of a GPT-5.2 Prompt: \n\n1. Role\nDefine a clear role for the model to adopt.\n\n2. Task\nState exactly what you want it to do.\nBe explicit about the desired action or outcome.\n\n3. Context\nGive the model everything it needs to perform well.\nInclude background details, constraints, examples. \n\n4. Reasoning Instruction\nPrompt it to think through the problem.\nRequest that GPT-5 explain its reasoning, or follow a logical COT before giving the final answer.\n\n5. Output Format\nSpecify how you want the answer presented.\nList the format clearly (bullet points, numbered steps, tables, narrative paragraphs). \n\n6. Stop Conditions\nSet boundaries for the response. This could mean limiting the length, ending at a certain step. \n\nTo copy the best GPT-5.2 prompt, go to:Â \nâ†³ https://lnkd.in/dkcDCGb5"

  "text": "You're prompting ChatGPT-5.2 like it's ChatGPT-4.\n\nHere are 5 new prompt rules for GPT-5.2:\n\n1. Purpose: Say what NOT to do\nGPT-5.2 gives you more than you asked for.\nExtra code. Role: Add a \"keep it simple\" rule\nGive it a job title, but don't confuse it.\nMixed instructions mess it up.\n\nFix: \"You are [expert]. If something is unclear, go with the simpler choice.\"\n\n3. Instructions: Stop the play-by-play\nGPT 5.2 knows what do if it has the right goal.\nFocus on the goal more than the steps.\n\nFix: \"Focus on the goal completion. I will consider it a success once we [target] for [audience].\"\n\n4. Manner: Give Exact Lengths\nWords like \"short\" or \"brief\" are too vague.\nBe specific. Use numbers.\n\nFix: \"3-6 sentences\" or \"max 5 bullets\" or \"2 sentences for yes/no.\"\n\n5. Effort: The Default Changed\nThinking mode is now \"none\" by default.\n\nFix: Always use \"Thinking mode\". Extended is even better. Understand ChatGPT is better with patience.\n\n6. I already tested what works with GPT-5.2.\nSo you don't have to.\n\nCopy my prompts: https://lnkd.in/dkcDCGb5.\n\n__\n\nChatGPT-5.2 is smarter but does too much.\n\nYour job is no longer to push it.   "text": "The new em-dash to recognize ChatGPT instantly:\n\n1. \"That's not [X]. That's [Y].\"\n2. \"In a world where [scary change], [virtue] becomes [advantage].\"\n3. \"Most people [lazy thing]. The few who win [disciplined thing].\"\n4. \"Here's the truth: [obvious statement].\"\n5. \"If you're not doing [X], you're already behind.\"\n\nI shared more here: https://lnkd.in/enzE6sF5.\n\nThese patterns are everywhere.\n\nLinkedIn. Emails. Cold outreach. Even serious business proposals. The em-dash was the first tell. Now it's these patterns.\n\nThey sound smart. But they say nothing specific.\n\nHere's how to fix your AI writing:\n\n1.Kill the meta commentary. \"Let's walk through...\" \"In this section, we will explore...\" Delete all of it. Just say the thing.\n\n2. Vary your sentence length. AI writes like a metronome. Every sentence is medium. Break the rhythm. Short hits hard. Then give room to breathe with a longer one.\n\n3. Take a stance. Not \"This may potentially offer benefits.\" But \"This works for small teams. Big companies will struggle with it.\"\n\n4. Use \"I\" and \"you.\" AI defaults to passive voice. You're writing for people. Talk to them.\nCut the padding. \"Highlighting the importance of...\" adds zero information. Delete it.\n\n5. Read this anti-AI guide: https://lnkd.in/enzE6sF5."
